comments: e/2 = lim_{n->infinity} n*(e - (1+1/n)^n). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Sep 17 2002An unusual infinite product for this number: e/2 = Product_{n>=1} ((1/n)!)^mu(n), where mu is the Mobius function (see Millane ref.). - _John M. Campbell_, Jun 14 2011
references: Jolley, Summation of Series, Dover (1961) eq. (161) on page 30.
links: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000
R. P. Millane., A product form of the MÃ¶bius transform, Whistler Center for Carbohydrate Research, Purdue University, West Lafayette, USA.
Roger H. Moritz, Summing series, PRIMUS, 1 (2) (2007) 212-219, Comment 2.
formula: 10*this constant = 5*exp(1) = Sum_{j>=0} j^3/j! [Jolley]. - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 03 2011Also, equals Sum_{j>=0} (1+j)/(1+2*j)!. [_Bruno Berselli_, May 25 2015]
prog: (PARI) { default(realprecision, 20080); x=exp(1)/2; for (n=1, 20000, d=floor(x); x=(x-d)*10; write("b019739.txt", n, " ", d)); } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, May 10 2009
crossrefs: Cf. A006083 = Continued fraction. - _Harry J. Smith_, May 10 2009
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
